questions.question_text:
A network technician needs to protect IP based servers in the network DMZ from being discovered by an intruder utilizing a ping sweep.
Which of the following should the technician do to protect the network from ping sweeps?

discussion.content:
And, again. Yes, C is technically correct, but so is using the proverbial sledgehammer (i.e. overkill) when a ball-peen hammer should be able to to do the job nicely. 

Question A is sufficient (block echo replies) without unnecessarily crippling the network and / or crucial troubleshooting tools for the resident network administrator.

As a matter of fact, blocking ICMP altogether (which is what Answer C 'nonrepudiatively' states) is deemed a handicap not worth paying the price due to the invaluable tool that the Groper tool (PIng) provides for daily tasks.

If interested (and highly recommended), read and bookmark the link below.

http://shouldiblockicmp.com/

choices.B: Place them in a separate subnet
choices.C: Place them between two internal firewalls
choices.D: Place them in the demilitarized zone D

questions.question_text:
There is a network looping problem after installing some switches. The switch vendor suggested the use of 802.1d.
Which of the following is the MOST probable reason the vendor made this suggestion?

discussion.content: It would be nice for content owner to review most of the comments with divided opinions here, which would really help some of us reading for our exams.

A is not correct, as the vendor recommended 802.1.d standard and not 802.1w which as links below are indicative of, are related to RSTP, the 'R' obviously referring to 'Rapid'.

The correct answer (unless the vendor recommended the wrong standard) would be C. 

STP > 802.1d
RSTP > 802.1w

Understanding Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (802.1w)
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/spanning-tree-protocol/24062-146.html
